p: Global average temperatures are projected to increase between 1.7 and 4.8°C by the end of this century [ 1, 2], with potential effects on human health, including mortality from extreme heat and cold, and changes in the ecology of infectious diseases [ 3– 5]. Climatic variability and extreme weather events have profound impacts on infectious diseases since fluctuations in temperature and precipitation influence both infectious agents (such as protozoa, bacteria, and viruses) and population dynamics of their vectors (such as mosquitoes, ticks, and rodents) [ 3, 6– 8]. Outbreaks of some diseases such as Ross River virus disease [ 9], malaria [ 10], meningitis [ 11] and Hantavirus Cardiopulmonary Syndrome (HCPS) [ 12] have been associated with climate anomalies.
